--- title: "Lesson 11: Urban Land Cover Change Detection Using Remote Sensing" author: "Dr. Kam Tin Seong
Assoc. Professor of Information Systems" institute: "School of Computing and Information Systems,
Singapore Management University" date: "last-modified" date-modified: "last-modified" format: revealjs: width: 1600 height: 900 show-notes: false slide-number: true show-slide-number: 'all' editor: visual execute: freeze: true --- ## Content - Why monitoring urban land cover change? - Urban land cover change detection methods: - Pre- and Post-Classification Change Detection, - Pixel-Based Change Detection, and\ - Object-Based Change Detection. ## Pre- and Post-Classification Change Detection This method involves classifying land cover in images from different time periods and then comparing the classified maps to identify changes. ## Pixel-Based Change Detection This approach directly compares pixel values in different images to detect changes. ## Object-Based Change Detection This method analyzes images by grouping pixels into objects, which are then compared to identify changes. ## Post-Classification Comparison Change Detection ![](img/image1.jpg) ## Per-Pixal Post-Classification Comparison ::::: columns ::: {.column width="40%"} - Rectified Landsat Thematic Mapper data of an area centered on Fort Moultrie, SC, obtained on (a) November 9, 1982, and (b) December 19, 1988 (RGB = bands 4, 3, 2). - Classification maps of the Fort Moultrie, SC, study area produced from the (c) November 9, 1982, and (d) December 19, 1988, Landsat TM data. Some barren land is included in the Developed/Exposed Land category (original imagery courtesy of NASA). ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ![](img/image2.jpg) ::: ::::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ### ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - Change detection map of the Fort Moultrie, SC, study areas derived from analysis of November 11, 1982, and December 19, 1988, Landsat Thematic Mapper data. - The natures of the change classes selected for display are summarised in the **From–To Change Detection Matrix** (based on Jensen et al., 1993a). ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/image3.jpg) ::: ::::: ## OBIA, or Object-Based Image Analysis OBIA is a technique that segments an image into distinct objects (or segments) based on spatial, spectral, and textural characteristics, and then classifies these objects rather than individual pixels. ## How it works? - Segmentation: The first step is to segment the image into homogeneous regions (objects) using algorithms that consider pixel similarity. - Feature Extraction: Once the objects are created, features like spectral, spatial, and textural properties are extracted from each object. - Classification: Finally, these extracted features are used to classify each object into a predefined class. ## Advantages of OBIA - Improved Accuracy: By analyzing objects rather than pixels, OBIA can lead to more accurate classifications, especially for complex scenes. - Reduced Noise: OBIA can help reduce noise and improve the reliability of the classification results. - Efficiency: OBIA can be more efficient than pixel-based classification, especially for high-resolution images. - Applicability: OBIA can be applied to a variety of applications, including land use/land cover classification, forest mapping, mineral mapping, coastal zone studies, crop classification, and urban studies. ## Applications of OBIA - Land Use/Land Cover Classification: Identifying different types of land cover, such as forests, fields, and urban areas. - Forest Mapping: Mapping different types of forests and assessing forest health. - Mineral Mapping: Identifying and mapping different types of minerals. Coastal Zone Studies: Analyzing and mapping coastal zones and their features. - Crop Classification: Identifying different types of crops and assessing their health. - Urban Studies: Analyzing and mapping urban areas and their features. ## OBIA Post-Classification Comparison ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} In this example below, OBIA segmentation. Selected object-based segmentation of the Bluffton, SC, Pictometry International, 2007 and 2011 natural color aerial photography at (a,b) 40 scale, and (c,d) 120 scale (imagery courtesy of Beaufort County GIS Department) ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/image4.jpg) ::: ::::: ## ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} Post-classification change detection of Bluffton, SC, based on 2007 and 2011 Pictometry, Inc., natural color aerial photography and object-based im age analysis. a\) Classification of 2007 photography (rasterized). b\) Classification of 2011 photography (rasterized). c\) Union of 2007 and 2011 classification maps using GIS map overlay function with selected from–to classes highlighted. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](img/image5.jpg) ::: ::::: ::: {.cell} :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
